Description: Fourteen sherds, some joining, of Milesian Fikellura pottery oinochoe; white slip. Interior: glazed black (worn) above, unslipped below; small volute in added white on lip. Exterior: glazed black on rim; part of white eye below rim and rosettes; below, quintuple cable pattern around neck between bands of single short vertical strokes between narrow lines; below, decoration in off-vertical strips; from left, band of long horizontal stripes alternating black, with added red, and reserved; to right, band with gear pattern, then two bands of enclosed palmettes with red on petals separated by a dividing band consisting of short strokes between pairs of lines; at right, band of oblique stripes alternating black, with added red, and reserved.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The vessel possibly belongs to the same vase as Brussels A1782. The piece comes from a very elaborate 'feathered jug', finer than the namepiece of the Louvre group and similar in approach to a jug in Kassel (S. Kaufler, Die archaischen Kannen von Milet (diss. Bochum, undated) 152-3, figs. 37 and 38. Robinson identified the sherd as being Corinthian.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 118-9, no. 331, pl. XXXVI, no. 331)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 230, no. 157, p. 239, no. 253)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GF.157)
Walter-Karydi 1973 / Samische Gefässe des 6. Jahrhunderts vor Christi: Landschaftsstile ostgriechischer Gefässe (48, pl. 6)
